title: Obligations arguably owed by bitcoin developers to bitcoin owners - Farrer & Co
content:
The English Court of Appeal has recently ruled that the developers who look after bitcoin networks may owe fiduciary duties and duties in tort to the owners of that cryptocurrency. The High Court had earlier decided that no such obligations could ever be owed. It is important to note that in overturning that decision, the Court of Appeal has not finally decided that such obligations are owed. Instead, it has remitted the case back to the High Court for it to be fully argued on the law and the facts. However, this case is important because it looks set to establish the nature of the relationship between the developers and the owners of bitcoin and because it could also have wider impacts in extending the law on fiduciary obligations.

Background

In Tulip Trading Limited -v- van der Laan and Others, the Claimant (Tulip) says that its access to a bitcoin wallet that contained (as at April 2021) US$4bn of bitcoin had been disabled as a result of a hacking incident by a third party. As such the bitcoin is at risk of being stolen by the hackers. Tulip claims that its access to that account could be easily restored by the Defendants, who are sixteen bitcoin software developers (the Developers) of the network on which the account sits, so that the bitcoin could be moved to a secure wallet. Fourteen of the Developers dispute that they owe any legal obligations to Tulip to assist it. They also raise factual disputes, pointing out that enabling Tulip’s access to the wallet will not be straightforward. Further they say that if they are required to re-establish that access it will potentially undermine the foundation on which bitcoin has been established (ie that such access is solely determined by who holds the private key to the wallet). The Court of Appeal said these factual disputes were not for determination at this stage and the High Court had fallen into error in taking some of them into account in reaching its decision. Instead, at this preliminary stage of determining whether there is a serious issue to be tried, the court should take the facts as alleged by Tulip to be true and decide whether, based on this, there can be any obligations owed to them by the Developers.

Decision

The Court of Appeal said that it is arguable that the Developers owe Tulip fiduciary duties to act to protect Tulip’s interests if a court requires the Developers to do so. The Court of Appeal accepted that this would be a significant extension to the law in this area, but also noted that the law on fiduciary relationships could be developed to deal with new situations such as that created by the development of bitcoin.

The essence of the decision is that the Court of Appeal accepted that there is a realistic argument that the Developers control the bitcoin software and are able to make decisions about the bitcoin which has been placed under their care by the owners of it. These are classic features of a fiduciary relationship which arguably therefore impose fiduciary obligations on the Developers to owners of bitcoin like Tulip. The extent of those obligations includes an obligation on the Developers not to act in their own self-interests when making decisions and exercising the powers that they have, and may also extend to a positive obligation to act as Tulip are requesting by restoring its access to the wallet in which the bitcoin is held.

Implications

The essence of this decision appears to be that if Tulip is right that bitcoin to the value of US$4bn is at risk because of the activity of hackers then why shouldn’t the law impose an obligation (whether fiduciary or tort based) on someone else to take steps to remove that risk, assuming that those required steps are not unduly onerous?

This illustrates that if High Court finds that the Developers do owe fiduciary duties to Tulip in the way that is being alleged, this could have far-reaching consequences in establishing obligations in a much wider range of situations, whether the parties intended this or not. For example, what if information is held in an email account of a deceased person which would be of great value to the beneficiaries of that person’s estate? Could a fiduciary or other obligation be placed on the controller of that account to allow access to it so that the information can be obtained?

Clearly, we will have to wait to see what the High Court decides when the case is fully argued, but the Court of Appeal has at least opened the door to the imposition of legal obligations on bitcoin developers to bitcoin owners.

title: SEC boss: "All tokens except Bitcoin are securities" - Trending Topics SEE
content:
Coinbase, Kraken, Paxos, Terraform Labs, Ripple – and maybe Binance soon too: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is taking increasingly tough action against crypto companies. Anyone who reads and follows the lawsuits and the specialist reports closely knows that all of this always comes down to one key question: Are cryptocurrencies just digital commodities (similar to gold) or digital vouchers (e.g. for one dollar like stablecoins), or are they something completely different: securities, i.e. digital shares, shares in companies.

There has been a dispute over this question for many years. At least since the SEC’s lawsuit against Ripple, which involves billions, courts have been dealing with the question of whether XRP and other tokens should actually fall under securities laws. Just as an Apple share is regulated, ETH, BNB, or SOL would also have to be regulated. Yes, you read that correctly. Even Ethereum is considered by the SEC and its powerful boss Gary Gensler as so-called “securities”.

“Always a group in the middle”

“Everything other than bitcoin, you can find a website, you can find a group of entrepreneurs, they might set up their legal entities in a tax haven offshore, they might have a foundation, they might lawyer it up to try to arbitrage and make it hard jurisdictionally or so forth,” said Gensler in an interview with New York Magazine. Behind all cryptocurrencies except bitcoin would be people using a variety of complex and legally opaque mechanisms to promote their tokens and attract investors.

Some would use tricks and sell the tokens overseas first. “But at the core,” Gensler said, “these tokens are securities because there’s a group in the middle and the public is anticipating profits based on that group.” While Bitcoin is a provably decentralized network (albeit with partially strong mining associations), Gensler also makes the very uncomfortable assumption that ether is also a security. And if ETH is a security, is Vitalik Buterin the CEO of the Ethereum company that issued these securities illegally (because they were not registered)? And then did Binance, Coinbase, Kraken and Co. trade illegal securities and make billions with it?

SEC cracks down on key players

The SEC’s lawsuit against Terraform Labs and its fugitive founder Do Kwon for issuing LUNA and UST and promoting so-called “wrapped” tokens like wLUNA speaks for itself. In the USA there is the notorious Howey test, which is supposed to clarify in 4 questions/points whether something is security or not. These would be:

An investment of money: is it a cash investment?

in a common enterprise: Are you investing in a company?

with expectations of a profit: Is there a profit expectation?

to be derived from the efforts of others: Are third parties responsible for generating the profit?

According to the SEC, the matter is clear in the case of wLUNA and UST: both wLUNA and UST are clearly securities for the US authorities because they could be exchanged for LUNA and thus served as proof of security. There was also a lawsuit against Coinbase to clarify whether and which of the nine tokens in question (AMP, RLY, DDX, XYO, RGT, LCX, POWR, DFX, and KROM) are actually securities. Luckily for Coinbase, the case was won with a dismissal of a lawsuit alleging illegal token sales.

But just days later, Kraken paid the SEC a $30 million fine for allegedly violating securities laws for its staking service. Again Coinbase had to come out and emphasize again. “Coinbase’s staking services are not securities. We will happily defend this in court if necessary,” it said in a tweet. This also shows that there is a major confrontation between the SEC and Coinbase. And that will ultimately clarify the question of whether tokens are securities or not.

Somewhere along your bitcoin investing journey, you’ll need to know how to cash out bitcoin or how to sell bitcoin. Fortunately, there are many different methods for cashing out your bitcoin, making it easy to convert it back to fiat currency. Understanding the different methods for cashing out can help you choose an affordable and convenient option for your financial needs.

How To Cash Out Your Bitcoin

Here is a look at seven simple ways to cash out your bitcoin.

Use a crypto exchange Sell through a broker Peer-to-peer trades Convert your bitcoin to another crypto Use a crypto debit card Shop at stores that accept bitcoin Use a bitcoin ATM

Keep reading to learn more about each of these options.

1. Sell Your Bitcoin Using a Crypto Exchange

Selling your bitcoin on a crypto exchange is one of the most common options for cashing out, but it can take longer than other methods and have higher transaction fees. A bank transfer from a crypto exchange typically takes between four and six business days, and you might have to pay transaction fees that could range between 0.5% and 2% each. However, it’s easy to set up a crypto exchange account and complete the transaction. Simply set up an account, complete verification processes, deposit or buy bitcoin to keep in your account and then transfer it to your bank when you’re ready.

Investing for Everyone

2. Sell Your Bitcoin Through a Broker

With traditional investing, a broker helps complete financial transactions using your funds. A crypto broker acts similarly, making crypto transactions based on your investment goals. Using a broker may be a good option for beginner investors, and it may be more suitable for those who want to make smaller crypto purchases.

3. Sell Your Bitcoin With a Peer-to-Peer Trade

Peer-to-peer trades may reduce transaction time and fees. However, you must be aware of how to complete peer-to-peer trades safely to avoid scams and fraudulent buyers. The safest option for peer-to-peer trades is to use a reputable peer-to-peer platform like LocalBitcoins. You can sign up and choose an ideal location for your buyer, as well as send trade requests on the platform’s marketplace. Many peer-to-peer platforms will also offer escrow options so that your bitcoin isn’t released until you receive payment.

4. Convert Your Bitcoin to Another Crypto

If you’re looking to get rid of your bitcoin specifically, you could also choose to convert it to another cryptocurrency. This gives you the opportunity to stay in cryptocurrency investing without holding too much bitcoin. However, you would need to transfer it to your bank account in the future to cash out for fiat currency, which could add more time and fees. In addition, you will also need to choose a crypto exchange that allows for more trading pairs and that supports multiple types of cryptocurrencies.

5. Use a Crypto Debit Card

Crypto debit cards are good for investors who don’t want to sell off large amounts of bitcoin. Instead, you can use the crypto debit card to make smaller purchases directly with vendors and stores, similar to regular debit cards. Many crypto debit cards also allow you to earn cash back and other rewards, as well as access ATMs. Some crypto debit cards will also allow you to add funds to your account using multiple types of cryptocurrencies or fiat currency.

Investing for Everyone

6. Shop at Stores That Accept Bitcoin

If you don’t want to transfer funds to your bank account, you can save time by shopping directly with stores that accept bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies as a payment method. However, be aware that there may be high transaction fees. In addition, the fluctuating price of cryptocurrency can affect the purchase price and refunds. Therefore, you may choose to only use cryptocurrency for large in-store purchases, rather than small everyday purchases.

7. Use a Bitcoin ATM

Bitcoin ATMs connect to platforms like crypto exchanges to facilitate buying and selling transactions. While some bitcoin ATMs will only allow you to buy bitcoin, you can also find some that allow you to sell your bitcoin and immediately receive cash, similar to a traditional ATM. You must have an account already set up with the platform. Then, you can simply enter your wallet address to cash out.

Final Take

Overall, it’s fairly easy to cash out your bitcoin. You can choose from various methods depending on your investing goals and spending decisions. However, consider factors such as timing, fees and crypto taxes. Choose a method that is convenient and affordable by researching each platform’s transfer times and transaction fees.

title: What is Bitcoin Halving: Effects And Future - ClearTax
content:
If you are a Bitcoin miner, you may have heard of the term called Bitcoin halving. It is a process that occurs after a set number of blocks are mined.

Bitcoin halving affects the investors, miners and the whole Bitcoin ecosystem. Let's discuss it in detail.

Bitcoin halving

Bitcoin halving is an event in which block rewards for mining Bitcoins are cut in half. This happens after the mining of every 210,000 blocks or roughly four years. This way, Bitcoin enforces artificial price inflation to ensure a steady rise in its value. This process will continue until miners completely mine the 21 million Bitcoins on this blockchain.

The last Bitcoin halving event took place on 11 May 2020. The current reward for mining a Bitcoin block is 6.25 BTC.

Besides miners getting lower block rewards, the rate at which new Bitcoins enter circulation also reduces. This, in turn, inflates its price as its demand increases due to the lower amount of new supply.

Generally, a huge crash always follows a price rise, but the value of Bitcoin after the crash is certainly more than the value of this crypto coin before the halving event.

For example, after the halving of 2016, in 2017-2018, Bitcoin’s value rose to $20,000. Like any rise in the market, it is followed by a crash, bringing down its value to $3,200. It may seem like a heavy crash, but before halving, Bitcoin’s value was at $650, increasing its value.

Effects of Bitcoin halving

Bitcoin halving has a chain effect. All individuals related to the currency, namely its miners and investors, are affected.

As the mining rewards per block halves, the supply of new coins becomes less. As a result, the price of each coin increases. The reward for miners may be less than before, but the increase in the coin's value makes up for it. Also, for miners, Bitcoin halving can lead to the consolidation of their ranks as individual miners.

If Bitcoin halving does not cause a rise in demand and value, the blockchain will reduce the mining difficulty on the network. This will make it easier for the miners to validate a block. Though block rewards are still low, the number of blocks miners can find will increase, keeping them in profit.

However, there is a catch. Reducing block rewards makes mining difficult for individuals and small mining pools. Large corporate companies are mining Bitcoins 24/7, and competing with them can be very costly.

According to experts, Bitcoin’s mining capacity is counter-cyclical to its price. As its price increases, the total number of miners diminishes and vice versa. A 51% attack is always probable after a Bitcoin halving as many miners move out of this network.

For investors, a Bitcoin halving event is always good news. The anticipation of a halving event always increases trading activities on exchanges. Take note that the rate at which the price of Bitcoin will increase after the halving is based on several market factors.

Bitcoin halving value over time

Upon its release, Bitcoin had a block reward of 50 Bitcoins. Its first halving occurred in 2013, and the block rewards went down to 25. In 2016, rewards fell to 12.5; after 2020, its current reward is 6.25. The next expected halving should occur in 2024, and its estimated block reward value will be 3.125 Bitcoins.

The value of Bitcoins has risen after every halving and held a price that was higher than the one before the event. Before the 2012 halving, the value of Bitcoins was around $11. Due to the halving, it rose a hundred times within a year. During the second halving of July 2016, Bitcoin’s value fluctuated from around $500 to $1,000 for a few months and reached a high of $20,000 by the end of December 2017. After the May 2020 halving, Bitcoin had a bull run and climbed from $9,000 to $30,000.

The future of Bitcoin mining

One question that always bugs miners is what will happen after all the blocks on the Bitcoin blockchain are mined. Will mining come to an end?

The simple answer is no. Bitcoin is a blockchain that works on the Proof-of-Work (PoW) consensus. Miners can validate blocks by solving critical mathematical problems and validating transactions. This removes the need for any third party to validate transactions, and miners also gain new coins in the process as rewards.

This reward is justified as miners must invest a lot of time and money in this process. Plus, there is intense competition from other miners that need to be taken into account. Miners use powerful ASIC computers that go through trillions of hashes per second to find the right hash to validate a block on the network.

The intense competition also ensures that any particular miner cannot pull off a 51% attack by gaining excessive control on a blockchain.

Thus, mining is a very necessary activity on a blockchain that works on the PoW mechanism. After mining all Bitcoin blocks is complete, miners will still be responsible for validating transactions. Furthermore, they will get transaction fees as their rewards. This way, miners can still act as validators of the transactions occurring on the network.

This system of reward for mining will go on at least till 2140 when the set limit of 21 million BTC is reached.

If you are currently a Bitcoin miner or thinking of mining this cryptocurrency, then Bitcoin halving will give you numerous opportunities to earn a profit. You can always hold your newly minted coins till the price appreciates and reaches a higher level. Alternatively, you can also stake them on an exchange platform to provide liquidity to other traders.

“According to me, the crypto winter is far from being over. We should once again be testing lower prices if not lower bottoms. We have seen some relief because money came into the market in hopes that there will be no further interest rate hikes. Also, the FTX crisis and before that the Luna crisis has now started getting forgotten and in the absence of any more new fraudulent activity coming up, people are feeling confident again,” says, Founder,Crypto prices are determined by three things -- one, which has nothing to do with crypto which is macroeconomics. US interest rates are 19 times higher than they were one year ago so 0.25 to 4.75, this has been the biggest driver of the crash but this has also been the driver of some relief we saw recently. The other two problems are very crypto centric. One is there are a lot of protocols and tokens that came out in the market and could only survive in the bull market. One by one they are crashing and then, of course, the ever persistent scams and frauds that may come up. This is the buzz in the crypto market.It would require me to have astrological ability to answer that with precision. In the absence of that I will give you my guess with a disclaimer that I am not a financial advisor. According to me, the crypto winter is far from being over. We should once again be testing lower prices if not lower bottoms. We have seen some relief because money came into the market in hopes that there will be no further interest rate hikes. Also, the FTX crisis and before that the Luna crisis has now started getting forgotten and in the absence of any more new fraudulent activity coming up, people are feeling confident again.Unlike the stock market which has such a long track record, in crypto we have had only four bull markets so far. So, we do not have too much of a track record. What we have seen is that in all cases, when the bear market ended, it was preceded by much more than one year of sideways movement of prices.In the previous bear market, the sideways movement was around the $10,000 mark. This time it is around the $20,000 mark. So even if we are looking at new players coming in or we are looking at money coming into the market. There are lots of people just waiting to sell at even slightly improved prices. So, prices going up is very unlikely in the near future or substantially up. There are some reasons why it might go down. I am clenching my teeth and even preparing for Q1 25 kind of revival though I suspect it will happen much earlier, maybe in early 24.One very interesting statistic which your viewers may not know is that only Bitcoin and Ethereum are two tokens which have survived more than one bull market and that is very interesting. That means when the bear market comes, the previous heroes do not remain heroes anymore. This time, barring Luna and FTT, that is a FTX token called FTT, we have not seen the demise of any major tokens and that worries me. Some of them might be coming up especially because crypto projects actually use their own tokens as if it is a currency and when the value of these tokens and currencies go down, their ability to buy and perform operations go down. Currently they are only firing people. We have not seen worse action than that. My worry is if some of that happens, prices could go down further.If you are looking at a global level, roughly 1% of the people who participate in all asset markets, real estate, forex, equity, mutual funds, etc, participate in crypto markets. The fact is that sentiment of this 1% is very different from the sentiment of the remaining 99% who have not yet come in. The remaining 99% still remain sceptical. They are not even sure that Bitcoin would not go down to zero for instance, but that is not the sentiment of people within the crypto markets. They are trying to be selective and look for companies that may have some more survival, some are going for the major tokens which is Bitcoin and Ethereum. The sentiment amongst crypto investors is pretty decent. Non-crypto investors are staying away.I always have buy orders at various prices and based on the percentage, not on amounts. I have bought all the way down to 15,700 on Bitcoin and my highest purchase has been around the 21,500 marks which was on the way down, not on the way up, which is very important. At present, I fear that all my buy orders which are much lower than present prices may not get fulfilled.Yesterday, one of the Emirates in the United Arab Emirates called Ras Al Khaimah actually opened a crypto free zone. In the last one week, Hong Kong has announced favourable crypto regulations. What we are finding is that there are several pockets around the world where more and more favourable regulations are happening. Even in the US, in the state of Wyoming, in the last one year, we have seen some very positive regulation.On the India front, while they may not officially agree to it, I always sense that there is a difference of opinion between the Reserve Bank of India and the Finance Ministry. Even in the G20, the Finance Minister continued her repeated mention that she would work with international collaboration while the Reserve Bank of India governor actually talked about the fact that we should consider a ban. Since the next discussion in G20 is only in October, it is fair to say that we have a little break and a respite of at least the next 10 months before this topic of ban comes up again.Let us consider two scenarios; one, eventually the whole world will ban crypto, in which case India will look like a visionary. I think the world is headed in the opposite direction and that is regulation. If that happens, given India's tech talent, given India's English speaking population and young population, I fear we are going to miss the bus.I fear that like we have done in the internet, e-commerce and social media, where we had to play catch up and by the way, we caught up pretty well, even here we are going to be condemned to do that. So I would require some visionary thinking from the central bank and finance ministry, recognize the direction in which the winds are blowing globally and align India to maximize its benefit from that.Regrettably, yes, and scams arise for three reasons; one is people come up with fraudulent activity as they literally are fly-by-night operators. If regulations come in, that should reduce.The second one is technological failures such as the one we saw in Luna. Now in this situation, we are just too early, pretty much like when debit cards came here. Debit cards had all the time. Despite more debit cards today, we are seeing that less. I think that is the industry that we are going up.The third one is that today the people who are in the crypto industry and I am talking of the likes of exchanges as well as other start-ups, are focused fundamentally on customer acquisition and not customer education. As a result, the customers, even the ones who are making profits are actually doing it by ignorance. When the audience is ignorant, there will be people who will prey upon that ignorance.If you look at India versus the rest of the world, we have a distinction. In India, the conservative financial investor is largely staying away from crypto markets. The people who invest in mutual funds, the people who have been investing in the stock market for decades, most of them have not touched crypto. It is the people who are in the 18-32 age group that accounts for 85% of crypto investors. Now, these people are investing despite hearing once every two or three months from the RBI that there should be a ban. So that means these people are the wild risk takers. So if a policy comes in, we bring in a new breed of larger relatively more conservative investors. At that point of time, we should see a reduction in the sort of speculative activity you see and hence a reduction in scams.There are two different categories although it sounded like one. The ones who have made severe losses are not necessarily the ones who have lost all hope. So here is the thing. Pretty much like any asset class, just because you may have lost 50%, 80% does not mean that you will have to hold it because it has to go up. Though it can go up, that does not mean it will not go down first.Second, those who are considering swapping between one token and another, may have a very interesting strategy. Please move to bigger, larger cap, more established tokens. The really bad tokens that some of us may have purchased hoping to become rich overnight have shown that they have no future. To believe that they will come up is a little far-fetched.Finally, please do as much research as possible before you enter into this. This is definitely a high-risk asset class. I think it is a very promising asset class. This is all that I invest in but still lots of research is required.

title: Bitcoin: What it is and How it Works - Kenyan Wallstreet
content:
Bitcoin is the star of the cryptocurrency craze. It has generated a lot of buzz on the internet and many people want to invest in bitcoin because of its profitability. Despite its anonymous nature, bitcoin has a potential to change the way we bank, make transactions, and view money. The world is learning more about cryptocurrencies and bitcoin, and it is expected that bitcoin will be the first common currency to be employed in the entire world in the near future. Engaging with Casumo partners could offer insightful ways into the merging worlds of cryptocurrency and online gaming, showcasing the transformative power of bitcoin and other digital currencies.

Investing in bitcoin is quite easy, but most people are nervous to start. It makes sense to only want to invest in something you understand. Trading in bitcoin requires skill and expertise and bitcoin investors can either self trade or do it with the help of a professional broker. In this article we are going to look at what bitcoin is, how it works, how to start investing in bitcoin and the risks associated with investing in bitcoin.



ADVERTISEMENT

What is Bitcoin?

Bitcoin, normally abbreviated as BTC, is a virtual currency controlled by a decentralised user base and is not controlled by the whims of Central Bank authority or National government. Bitcoin was introduced by one Sakoshi Nakamoto and is the most popular type of cryptocurrency for investment. Other cryptocurrencies available are often known as altcoins. When we say bitcoin is virtual, it means that it has no physical backing and can be sent electronically from one user to the next, anywhere in the world.

Bitcoin Mining

The value of bitcoin is known to fluctuate because of a finite number of coins available as a result of bitcoin mining. Bitcoin mining involves “digging up” of bitcoins and bringing them to light, a little at a time. There are bitcoin protocols that contain bitcoins which have not yet been brought out. Bitcoin protocol stipulates that a maximum of 21,000,000 million bitcoins will exist at one point, in the future.

What bitcoin miners do is that they bring these bitcoin up a few at a time. Once the maximum number of bitcoins to be mined is reached, no more coins are mined. When the bitcoin protocol allows for a larger supply, bitcoin mining continues. Mining ensures fairness, stability and security of bitcoins. This is as a result of scarcity and the blockchain technology that bitcoin embraces. Bitcoin miners get paid in transaction fees for creating blocks of validated transactions and including them in blockchain.

How Does Bitcoin Work?

With a coin, you can buy products or services. However, bitcoin has no tangible attributes, but it operates almost in the same way as normal currency. Bitcoin has a decentralised structure, which means there is no interference from the government or the Central Bank and users are in complete control of their transactions.

A bitcoin miner gets money after creating blocks and incorporating them into the blockchain through transaction fees. Once a bitcoin miner obtains bitcoins, he or she keeps them in a wallet before deciding to sell them to another investor at a price. You can buy either low quality or high quality bitcoins. Bitcoin can also be used as a payment method for the purchase of goods and services and is accepted by some merchants.

How to Start Investing in Bitcoin

To invest in bitcoin, you have to first buy them on bitcoin exchange. When you are buying bitcoins, it is good to buy high quality bitcoin, but you can opt for either according to how much you are willing to invest. When buying bitcoins, you have to consider the payment method,the bitcoin platform and where you want your bitcoins to go (wallet). You must also have a bank account, personal identification information and a good internet connection to trade.

One such exchange, eToro, allows investors to purchase and trade cryptocurrencies quickly and securely. Since it is a popular online trading platform that provides a secure and easy way to buy bitcoin with eToro and other cryptocurrencies such as Ethereum, Litecoin, etc., quickly and conveniently.

Here are the simplified steps:

Join a bitcoin exchange. Bitcoin exchanges allow you to make purchases of bitcoins. Although there is no bitcoin company, there are many cryptocurrency exchanges that can help you get started in your bitcoin investment. Some of the most popular exchanges include Coinbase, Binance and Kraken.

Get a bitcoin wallet. Once you have purchased your bitcoins, they have to be stored in a wallet. There are two types of bitcoin wallets: a hot wallet and a cold wallet. Your cryptocurrency exchange provider is responsible for operating your hot wallet, whereas you can operate your own cold wallet. Some of the best bitcoin wallets include Electrum and Mycelium.

Have a bank account. A bank account is a necessary part of bitcoin investment because it allows you to connect your wallet. This makes the sale and purchase of bitcoins easier.

Place your bitcoin order. Here, you can either buy a whole bitcoin, which is quite costly, or a fraction of a single bitcoin.

Check on your bitcoin investment. Once you have bought your bitcoins, you have an option of holding them in your wallet until they appreciate in value, make online transactions or trade your coins with other bitcoin investors.

Risks Associated With Bitcoin Investment

Before you decide to invest in bitcoin, it is necessary to be wary of these risks.

Security risk. Bitcoin investment operates on a digital platform. If you do not have a wallet and you forget or misplace you key there is rarely a way to retrieve your coins. Hacking is also a serious risk, since there is no way to retrieve lost or stolen bitcoins.

Fraud risk. Hackers gain personal information and use that for transaction fraud, where they make purchases in your name and never refund the bitcoins. This is one of the biggest risks of bitcoin investments.

Market risk. The price of bitcoin is volatile. Because of this fluctuation, a bitcoin investor faces the risk of losing a lot of money once the bitcoin value goes down.

Insurance risk. Bitcoin is not insured by the government, hence there will be no compensation in case of loss arising from risk.

Final Thoughts

Bitcoin is a viable investment for any average investor. Bitcoin has facilitated faster payment and transactions at significantly low fees in place of traditional banks and Many people believe that bitcoin has an ability to bring about a shift from a cash to a cashless society. However, before you start investing in bitcoins, it is important to understand the fundamentals of this financial market. For starters, make sure you do your research and learn as many important concepts as possible that will help you navigate this type of investment easily. Talk to experts and have someone to help you through this investment process.
